block.p: Haditha Inquiry Negligent, U.S. General Concludes The second-ranking American commander in Iraq has concluded that senior Marine officers were negligent in failing to investigate more aggressively the killings of Iraqi civilians by marines in Haditha, Defense Department officials said.
Iraqi soldiers stormed a building in Baghdad, killing or wounding between 30 and 40 gunmen and capturing a high-level Shiite militia commander, the American military command said.

Five Killed in Gaza Clashes Another five Palestinians were killed in more sporadic clashes across northern Gaza, as relatives and militants mourned those killed in fierce fighting with Israeli troops.
Mexican Uncertainty Persists Mexico hung in limbo as tensions rose between those seeking a recount in the presidential race and those seeking to accept Felipe Calderón as the winner and move on.

Bush Reacts to North Korea President Bush said he believed the nation's missile defense system would have had a ''reasonable chance'' of shooting down a missile launched by North Korea, and he said he was determined to use the United Nations to set ''red lines'' for North Korea's behavior.
Japan introduced a Security Council resolution calling for sanctions against North Korea for its missile test-firings, but China opposed the move.
Ukraine Coalition Collapses President Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine suffered a new political defeat when his coalition collapsed only two weeks after it was formed.

Bush Says Justices Endorsed Guantánamo President Bush, in his most detailed comments to date on the Supreme Court's rejection of his decision to put detainees on trial before military commissions, said that the court had tacitly approved his use of the detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

Immigration Hearing in Texas Terrorists as well as illegal immigrants could slip across a southern United States border that is porous and vulnerable, law enforcement and immigration agents said, as Republicans from the House of Representatives took the immigration reform debate to the Texas border.

Judge Blocks ID Requirement For the second time, a state judge has blocked a Republican-sponsored effort to require Georgia voters to present government-issued photo identification cards before they can cast a ballot.

Internet as Lifeline for Troops For this generation of deployed soldiers, the Internet, which is now widely available on military bases, has softened the blow of long separations between them and their families, helping loved ones stay in daily touch.

NASA Studies Shuttle Images Engineers and analysts scrutinized images of the shuttle Discovery for damage that may cause problems in the heat of re-entry. They said the shuttle ascended in a clean state and narrowed their analysis to a few unresolved issues.

N.Y. Tunnels Were Targets In Bomb Plot, Police Say Authorities overseas have arrested one man and taken two others into custody for suspicion of planning suicide bombings in train tunnels beneath the Hudson River between Manhattan and New Jersey, officials said. Five other men are being sought for their alleged involvement in the plan. A1

New Jersey's Budget Woes Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey has shown his political rivals that he has the resolve to win a showdown with a Legislature grown accustomed to borrowing with abandon. But his budget plan will probably have only a modest effect on the factors that have made New Jersey, one of the nation's richest states, one of the most fiscally troubled. B1

Testing State Terrorism Law A construction worker who has been in jail for three years awaiting trial will become the first person tried under New York's 2001 antiterrorism statute. But he does not belong to Al Qaeda or Hamas -- he is a member of a street gang that terrorized Mexicans in the west Bronx, prosecutors say. B1

A Star-Studded Pardon Plea The release of music producer Dallas Austin from a Dubai jail this week, quick on the heels of his conviction for drug possession, turns out to be a story of high-level string-pulling on the part of Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the conservative Utah Republican; Lionel Richie, the singer; Quincy Jones, the music entrepreneur, and an array of other well-connected people, the producer's laywers said. A1
Employers added only 121,000 jobs in June, the government reported, indicating that the economy is slowing under the combined weight of high energy prices and rising interest rates.
Corporate profit warnings and record oil prices overshadowed a benign jobs creation report and sent stocks sharply lower.

G.M. to Begin Alliance Talks At the request of its biggest shareholder, the board of General Motors directed its chief executive to begin ''exploratory talks'' with Renault and Nissan about a three-way alliance.
Editorials: Global warming and the courts; a St. Petersburg story; the dry half of the country; Dorothy Samuels on the Deficit Reduction Act.
